skills.name: Round numbers to one decimal place
Round numbers to two decimal places
Round numbers to three or more decimal places

explanations.A: Not quite, think carefully about the digit after .1 and what effect that has on your answer.
explanations.B: There are 7 hundredths, and so because 7 is a 5 or above, we have rounded the 1 tenth up to 2 tenths, giving us an answer of 154.2.
explanations.C: You're very close! Think carefully about which digits are affected here by rounding.
explanations.D: Not quite. Think carefully about which digits are affected here by rounding. Make sure to check the digit after the 1 to see whether you round up or not.

explanations.A: There are 6 hundredths, and so because 6 is 5 or above, we have rounded the 2 tenths up to 3 tenths, giving us an answer of 58.3
explanations.B: Not quite, think carefully about the number in the hundredths column and what effect that has on your answer.
explanations.C: You're very close! Think carefully about which digits are affected here by rounding.
explanations.D: Not quite. Think carefully about which digits are affected here by rounding. Make sure to check the digit after the 2 to see whether you round up or not.

explanations.A: You're very close. Make sure your answer shows that you have rounded to 1 decimal place, and still has a number in the tenths column.
explanations.B: When rounding to 1 decimal place, anything beyond the tenths column is not kept. In this case, because the digit in the hundredths column is a 4, we can keep the tenths value the same. This means your answer is 0.0. It is important to keep one zero after the decimal point to show this is rounded to 1 decimal place.
explanations.C: Nearly! Remember to check whether the number in the hundredths column is 5 or above, and if not then the tenths column stays the same.
explanations.D: Not quite! You've actually rounded to two decimal places here instead of one :) Make sure you only have one digit after the decimal point.

explanations.A: You're very close. Make sure your answer shows that you have rounded to 1 decimal place, and still has a number in the tenths column.
explanations.B: Not quite! You've actually rounded to two decimal places here instead of one :) Make sure you only have one digit after the decimal point.
explanations.C: I think you've forgotten a digit! Make sure you keep all the digits up to the tenths column
explanations.D: When rounding to 1 decimal place, anything beyond the tenths column is not kept. In this case, because the digit in the hundredths column is a 2, we can keep the tenths value the same. This means your answer is 9.0. It is important to keep one zero after the decimal point to show this is rounded to 1 decimal place.

explanations.A: Not quite, think carefully about the digit in the thousandths column and what effect that has on your answer.
explanations.B: There are 6 thousandths, and so because 6 is 5 or above, we have to round the 1 hundredth up to 2 hundredths, giving us an answer of 3.52.
explanations.C: Not quite. Think carefully about which digits are affected here by rounding. Make sure to check the digit after the 1 to see whether you round up or not.
explanations.D: You're very close! Think carefully about which digits are affected here by rounding.

explanations.B: There are 8 thousandths, and so because 8 is 5 or above, we have to round the 7 hundredths up to 8 hundredths, giving us an answer of 11.48.
explanations.C: Not quite. Think carefully about which digits are affected here by rounding.
explanations.D: Not quite. Think carefully about which digits are affected here by rounding.

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you had the correct method but forgot to carry. Have a think about where 0.9999 and 0.10 would be on a number line to understand where this may have gone wrong.
explanations.B: You're very close. Make sure your answer shows that you have rounded to 2 decimal places, and still has digits in the tenths and hundredths columns.
explanations.C: Nearly! Remember to check whether the number in the thousandths column is 5 or above, and if it will affect the number before it.
explanations.D: This answer is correct :) There are 9 thousandths, and so because 9 is 5 or above, we have to round the 9 hundredth up to 10 hundredths, which is 1 tenth. That extra tenth then adds to the 9 tenths already there, giving us 10 tenths, which is 1 unit. This extra unit carries over to the 0 units and gives us an answer of 1.00. Notice that it is important to have two digits after the decimal point to show we've rounded to 2dp.

explanations.A: You're almost there! 9 hundredths does round to 10 hundredths, but it doesn't become 10.10
explanations.B: You're very close! Remember to show clearly that you've rounded to 2 decimal places
explanations.C: Make sure you've looked at the digit in the thousandths column and how rounding will affect the number before it.
explanations.D: This answer is correct :) There are 5 thousandths, and so because 5 is 5 or above, we have to round the 9 hundredths up to 10 hundredths, which is 1 tenth. That extra tenth then adds to the 9 tenths already there, giving us 10 tenths, which is 1 unit. This extra unit carries over to the 0 units and gives us an overall answer of 11.00. Notice that it is important to have two digits after the decimal point to show we've rounded to 2dp.

explanations.A: This answer is correct :) When rounding to three decimal places, you look to the fourth digit after the point (the 10 thousandths column), and if that number is a 5 or above then the digit in the thousandths column increases by 1, if not then the thousandths column stays the same. Here, 4 is less than 5, and so the 3 thousandths stay as they are. Giving an answer 20.153
explanations.B: Almost, you've rounded to two decimal places here
explanations.C: Not quite, remember to check if the fourth digit after the point is a 5 or above, only then will it affect the digits before. You can ignore the 5th digit after the point
explanations.D: Not exactly, only the 3rd digit after the point may be affected in this question.

explanations.A: Not exactly, only the 3rd digit after the point may be affected in this question.
explanations.B: Almost, you've rounded to two decimal places!
explanations.C: Remember to check whether the 4th digit after the point is a 5 or above, and use this to decide if the thousandths column will be affected.
explanations.D: This answer is correct :) When rounding to three decimal places, you look to the fourth digit after the point (the 10 thousandths column), and if that number is a 5 or above then the digit in the thousandths column increases by 1, if not then the thousandths column stays the same. Here, 8 is more than 5, and so the 6 thousandths increase by 1 to become 7 thousandths. Everything else stays the same, giving an answer 29.157.
